Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Undergraduate Engineering Education through Adaptive Learning and Student Data Analytics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving student learning in STEM by integrating personalized pre-class experiences that adapt individually to each student’s level of knowledge. Active learning in the classroom has been proven effective for strengthening student engagement and improving student learning outcomes. The flipped classroom is one popular active learning approach. In flipped classrooms, students learn basic information from resources such as online lecture videos and automated testing. This learning takes place at each students’ own pace, prior to the regular class lecture. Then, during the lecture period, students collaborate with their peers to solve problems that apply the knowledge they learned outside of class. This project aims to improve the flipped classroom approach by integrating personalized and adaptive pre-class content into each student's learning experiences. The use of adaptive lessons aligns well with "Advancing Personalized Learning," one of the National Academy of Engineering's 21st Century Grand Challenges.

Most engineering problems are complex; they may take a long time to solve and often do not have single solutions. To develop the ability to solve such problems, most undergraduate STEM students take a course in Numerical Methods. This project involves the development of adaptive lessons for a course in Numerical Methods and the assessment of the cognitive and affective learning outcomes of students in such courses at three diverse institutions: the University of South Florida, Arizona State University, and Alabama A&M University. A significant part of the assessment effort will focus on various demographic segments, including underrepresented minority, female, and Pell Grant students, to ensure that all materials work well across diverse student populations. Students' engagement with and performance in the adaptive lessons will also be analyzed in real-time to support student success. For example, proactive interventions and resources will be created that can be implemented as soon as students show signs of struggling in the course. The project restructures the Numerical Methods course as a flipped classroom with personalized, adaptive learning. This project will also compare a flipped classroom with and without the use of adaptive lessons relative to student cognitive and affective learning outcomes, and through analytics of student learning data. Metrics used in the investigation include both qualitative and quantitative measures of multiple assessments to verify the consistency of findings. The project will deliver instructional materials that facilitate best practices for teaching STEM courses in flipped mode with adaptive learning lessons, thereby contributing to the knowledge base for advancing personalized learning. Dissemination avenues include workshops, manuscripts, open education resource portals, and social media. This project is funded by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources program, which supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research in college-level STEM courses has indicated that active learning (students engage directly through activities and discussions) can improve comprehension and long-term retention. Evidence suggests this method can raise average grades by half a letter compared to traditional lectures and reduce failure rates by 55% compared with conventional classes. Moreover, it significantly narrows the passing rate gap between overrepresented and underrepresented students by 45%, highlighting the potential benefits of active learning approaches.

One way to incorporate active learning is by flipping the classroom, where students receive lecture content at home and participate in problem-solving exercises in the classroom. However, a challenge of the flipped classroom is ensuring that students are adequately prepared before class. To address this challenge, this project developed lessons on a commercially available adaptive learning platform to provide individualized learning experiences that respond to each student's performance and activity.

The project designed, revised, and enhanced adaptive lessons at three diverse universities for pre-class learning and preparation in a Numerical Methods course, a fundamental undergraduate subject for the most prevalent engineering majors in the country. These adaptive lessons allowed structured access to various educational resources, such as video lectures, textbook material, and simulations, while providing personalized learning paths based on evaluations of students' responses to quiz questions. A total of twenty-one simulations were also developed to support the main goals of the course. These cloud-based simulations operate efficiently across multiple devices and operating systems. Notably, a thorough assessment plan was implemented to evaluate both affective and performance outcomes related to adaptive learning, ensuring the project's results were valid and reliable.

The study identified improvements in the flipped classroom environment when an adaptive learning platform was utilized, with notable changes observed at two universities. Furthermore, the research highlighted enhanced student perceptions when adaptive learning was incorporated into the flipped classroom. These enhancements included a greater preference for flipped instruction, a higher perception of learning gains, and reduced feelings of imposed responsibility, required effort, or difficulties with problem-solving during class. Although direct assessment results varied by university and type of knowledge measure, they indicated that adaptive learning in the flipped classroom could be beneficial for underrepresented minority students, Pell Grant recipients, community college transfer students, and for tackling open-ended problems on exams. Overall, this research advocates using adaptive learning platforms in flipped STEM courses to encourage pre-class preparation and enhance learning outcomes.

The adaptive learning platform gathered data to develop a predictive model, which detected low-performing students early in the semester. This model took into account both student performance and their interactions with the platform. Identified students were given access to a one-on-one tutoring program. Those who participated in the program earned grades that were, on average, half a letter higher than those who did not. The students reported positive experiences, such as better understanding, improved grades, and practical applications discussed during sessions. They valued the personalized invitations, highlighting the significance of individualized support.

Based on the idea that active and collaborative student engagement enhances learning, this project established best practices for teaching a standard flipped STEM course utilizing adaptive learning techniques. These methods apply to various teaching modalities, such as blended classrooms and other STEM subjects. Adaptive learning can particularly benefit underrepresented minorities and non-traditional students, including community college transfers, by improving their academic performance and fostering a sense of inclusion and value within the educational environment.

Project materials were distributed via the open education resource portal (https://nm.MathForCollege.com) and social media platforms such as blogs (https://blog.AutarKaw.com) and YouTube (https://YouTube.com/NumericalMethodsGuy/). To engage a greater number of students, workshops for faculty were conducted at universities and regional engineering education conferences. The findings were presented at major engineering education and professional society conferences, and the project's conclusions were published in STEM education journals.
